title: Three youths wrongly jailed for murder changed police investigations forever
text:

When three innocent teenagers were cleared of murder after a botched investigation, the scandal sparked the biggest shake-up of police powers in history.

The travesty is now the subject of a BBC documentary which shows the appalling impact on those wrongly convicted. In 1972, officers were called to a blaze and found the body of 26-year-old Maxwell Confait, a male prostitute known as Michelle, who had been strangled.

Police later picked up three youths – Colin Lattimore, 18, Ronnie Leighton, 15, and Ahmed Salih, 14 – on suspicion of lighting a series of small fires nearby and pinned the murder on them.

They were held without a lawyer, without contact with a parent or guardian, with cops questioning them for as long as they liked.

(Image: Mirrorpix)

By 2am, after hours of endless ­interrogation, these vulnerable boys signed a statement confessing to the fire in Catford, South East London, and to Maxwell’s murder.

Colin had learning ­difficulties and the mental age of an eight-year-old. His family knew he was innocent.

“No way was he capable of murdering anyone,” brother Gary told a new BBC Two ­documentary Catching Britain’s Killers: The Crimes That Changed Us. “He was scared of his own shadow.

Nightmare

“Colin couldn’t read or write. He didn’t act like an 18-year-old man, he was more like an eight-year-old. He was a boy in a man’s body.”

(Image: BBC/Wall to Wall Media Ltd)

“Police were unsupervised and a law unto themselves,” says Baroness Hayter, a former magistrate.

It was the start of a nightmare for the trio. Ronnie was convicted of Maxwell’s murder, while Colin was found guilty of manslaughter with diminished responsibility. All three were found guilty of arson.

While Ahmed was sentenced to three-and-a-half years, Colin and Ronnie were handed life sentences.

“I remember people coming out with long faces and crying,” recalled Gary. “My dad, George, said,

‘The scales of justice? You might

as well rip them off and chuck them in the Thames’.” Ian Alexander, on the boys’ defence team, was also certain they were innocent. He said: “We felt they couldn’t have done it.”

(Image: BBC/Wall to Wall Media Ltd)

“It seemed an improbable story. That three boys would creep into a house, go into a room and strangle him. There wasn’t any sign of any struggle. It was very difficult to make a case against the police that a ­statement was made under duress. People didn’t believe police could behave badly.

“There was no ­independent record. It was the word of the police that was believed.”

Forensic evidence was uncertain.

No body ­temperature was taken at the time of death meaning they couldn’t pinpoint the moment of murder. Initially, the pathologist said time of death was between 6.30pm and 10.30pm.

(Image: PA Archive/PA Images)

Colin had a cast-iron alibi as he was at a local social club and seen by a number of witnesses. But the prosecution insisted one thing was certain – the confessions.

In 1974, two years after the murder, a young barrister called ­Jonathan Caplan, sitting on the National Council of Civil ­Liberties, received a letter from the ­Lattimore family pleading Colin’s case.

“I felt there had been an injustice,” said Jonathan. “The important thing was to get an independent pathologist to review the time of death.”

They found the murder likely took place between 8pm and 9pm, confirming the alibis.

The case was heard in the Court of Appeal and in 1975 the ­convictions were quashed and Colin, Ronnie and Ahmed were told they were cleared of all charges. “Everyone was ecstatic and jubilant,” told Gary. “Colin was in shock.”

(Image: Daily Record)

It became one of the first real ­miscarriages of justice to be exposed.

One month after the appeal, the Henry Fisher inquiry was announced.

It found aggression was used by police towards the youngsters. One allegedly got hit with a rolled up newspaper.

It criticised the police, saying the ­interviews should have been done in presence of parents.

It also concluded that interviews were oppressive and recommended there should be reform at the way suspects are treated at police stations.

But in a new blow it stated the trio were responsible for the fire and that Ronnie and Ahmed had killed Maxwell.

“I feel very angry because of what they did, how they fitted up my brother for something he didn’t do,” said Gary. “I still carry that anger because it changed everybody’s life. Colin came out of prison and struggled with life in general. It troubled him and ruined his life.”

New evidence emerged in 1980 that finally exonerated them. An inmate was overhead discussing murder in prison. He and the accomplice blamed each other so neither could be prosecuted. But the three boys’ names could be cleared.

Dubbed one of the most serious miscarriages of justice, it sparked a giant overhaul. The Police and Criminal Evidence Bill came in 1984, ­transforming the ­interrogation room and our rights. Maxwell’s real killer was never convicted.

“A change in the law was a massive thing,” Gary added. “We were very happy about the because it can’t happen any more. Another family can’t go through what we went through.”

Catching Britain’s Killers: The Crimes That Changed Us is on BBC Two on Wednesday at 9pm.
description: EXCLUSIVE: Dubbed one of the most serious miscarriages of justice, the 1972 investigation into a murdered prostitute sparked a giant overhaul in police tactics
authors: Bbc Wall To Wall Media Ltd
